newsitem.title: USA: US Rep. Archer-no effective date for cap gains yet.
newsitem.headline: US Rep. Archer-no effective date for cap gains yet.

text.p: House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Bill Archer said Tuesday that no effective date had been set yet for an expected capital gains tax cut.

"I'm not leaning toward anything right now, that's very much up for consideration and I'll be talking to Senator (William) Roth about it," Archer, a Texas Republican, told reporters. Roth, a Delaware Republican, is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
A capital gains tax cut was one of the components included in the budget deal announced Friday between congressional leaders and the White House.
There is some concern that investors may hold off on selling assets until they find out when a capital gains tax cut would go into effect.

Archer said he expected "markup" of tax legislation to occur "reasonably quickly" after the budget resolution is passed. A committee markup gives lawmakers the opportunity to amend proposed legislation.

"I want to have a package that will give relief to hard-hit middle-income families, particularly with children, and one that will have adequate incentives for savings and capital formation and job creation," Archer said. "I think there should be a very good balance between those two."

Asked whether Superfund money would be used to offset tax cuts, Archer replied: "I don't plan on putting any Superfund taxes into this tax bill until I see major structural reform of the spending program."
The one item that would definitely be included in his own tax plan would be the elimination of ethanol subsidies, Archer said.
On the airline ticket tax, Archer said, "I am hopeful that we will have a revised formula that we can put in place for a number of years into the future."
